PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 February, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow that, on behalf of the Opposition, I will be moving the following amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Sugar Amendment Bill 1985:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add ', but the Senate notes with great concern the plight of the industry generally and the communities dependent on the industry because of the failure of the Hawke Government to honour its pre-election promises to assist the depressed sugar industry'.

The Bill is merely a machinery piece of legislation to give effect to the five-year agreement which the Queensland and Federal governments entered into and which was signed on 28 June last year. The agreement actually runs from 1 July 1984 to 30 June 1989. The first agreement of this kind was actually entered into in 1923. In 1927 it was recognised that there could be legal problems in that the agreements which were being entered into had no complementary Commonwealth legislation, mainly because trade and embargoes were under Commonwealth influence. So, since 1927 similar pieces of machinery legislation to the one now before the Senate have been introduced into the Commonwealth Parliament.

This legislation proposes a marginal easing of the embargo. Might I say, again, that this will be done by agreement. This step has been taken not to reduce any effectiveness of the embargo but mainly to ease administrative difficulties. Clause 16, particularly clause 16 (2) (a) of the Schedule, deals with the easing of the embargo in respect of small packages and small consignments. This has been done because at times speciality sugars, which have been allowed in in small packages, could have been part of larger consignments in large containers and held up as they went through Customs. The Commonwealth and Queensland governments and the industry realise that this is a waste of resources. The Opposition welcomes the fact that an amicable arrangement has been entered into to produce this sensible agreement.

The Schedule to the Bill also mentions sugar rebates. The domestic rebate is to be discontinued. However, the export sugar rebate is to be continued, with minor changes. I might add that none of the rebates will cost the taxpayer anything. The cost is borne entirely by the industry.

I would now like to turn to the amendment and the concerns that many of us, particularly my National Party of Australia colleagues in Queensland, have about the future of the sugar industry. The sugar industry directly employs about 20,000 people. I suppose indirectly, working on the 5:1 formula which is generally accepted, about 100,000 other people are employed in some way as a result of the industry. I am thinking here of people who provide machinery, repairs, fertilisers, fuel and all the rest of it. Twenty years ago the sugar industry produced 1.99 million tonnes of sugar from 14.4 million tonnes of cane from 9,000 farms. Today 3.5 million tonnes of sugar are produced from 25.5 million tonnes of cane from 6,200 farms.

The sugar industry, as well as all the other primary industries, has not been sitting idly by as the cost structures gradually increase. The sugar producers, as well as all the other primary producers, have become more efficient. The problem is: What is the use of becoming efficient on their own farms if the on-costs past the farm gate are such that they become uncompetitive? That is the problem facing the sugar industry. It is the problem that has been facing all the primary industries to date. They have become efficient where they can be efficient, but the costs that are beyond their control-such as transport, handling, shipping and so on-have accelerated. That is one of the problems which the Government has not addressed.

Centralised wage fixing is proving to be a disaster in this area. The sooner this nation recognises that the wage fixing structures have to be exposed to market forces in this country, the sooner this country will be better off and the sooner we will become competitive again. Until that time we will be in all sorts of dire trouble. Many of the people who produce goods are not making money out of them and are, in fact, losing money. Despite that fact, 40 per cent of our export income comes from primary producers. Those producers are completely susceptible to market forces. Yet the wages structure in this country is not susceptible to market forces. Thus we see these massive increases in on-costs and the other problems that are facing this country. We are on a long, slippery slide from which we will not recover. Many people will be hurt unless we take some serious action in the near future.

Another problem facing the sugar industry is the European Economic Community and its surpluses-subsidised surpluses. Our producers, who are operating in a market situation, are afforded very little protection today. They receive nowhere near as much protection as the manufacturing industries receive. The protection afforded to the manufacturing sector has decreased, but not to anywhere near the extent as that afforded to primary producers. A subsidised surplus-I believe it is an accumulated surplus-of about 11 million tonnes of sugar is sitting in the EEC. This subsidised surplus is causing all sorts of problems on the world market. The Industries Assistance Commission says that our primary produce has to be priced on a world market basis. That is a ludicrous proposition when the EEC is holding surpluses, large surpluses and subsidised surpluses, in all sorts of primary produce. This means that the world market price bears no relationship to the actual cost of production or what the product is really worth. Such IAC reports are rather silly. The IAC has submitted such reports not only on the sugar industry but also on other industries such as the dairy industry. The sugar industry faces massive EEC subsidised surpluses and the possibility that they will be dumped on our traditional markets.

Despite all the problems confronting the sugar industry today, 3.5 per cent of the gross value of our rural production and 4.6 per cent of our total export income still come from sugar. For many years the sugar growers of Australia subsidised the domestic market. That fact seems to be lost on some of the detractors of the industry. For many years the export prices were higher than the domestic market prices. As a matter of fact, the Australian consumer is still in debt to the Australian sugar grower for those many years of high subsidisation. In the 1983 election campaign the Labor spokesmen made many promises. They went to north Queensland and promised underwriting. One of their promises was in part:
. . . in the current crisis, to give sympathetic consideration to an industry loan to the established Queensland and New South Wales industry.

In the 1984 election campaign there was an almost unprecedented demonstration by the sugar growers in Queensland. Twelve hundred people came from as far north as Mossman by bus and train to Brisbane to voice their concern. The response of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was in part:

I undertake on behalf of the Federal Government to you and to the industry that we will undertake a financial commitment to assist you on the basis that the review-which is accelerated as a result of co-operation with the State Government-move towards drawing up an overall package which is going to result in a strong and viable industry.
The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in a Press statement on 18 January, which was after the election-the Government won, of course-made no specific reference to the loan but did say in part:

As the Prime Minister has indicated to the Queensland Government, across the board assistance such as was raised before by the industry has shown to be overly expensive, undirected and largely ineffective in helping those growers most in need.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a contradiction of his first statement.

—It is indeed. But one statement was made before the election and one was made afterwards. What could we expect? That is the way the Labor Government is treating the sugar industry and it is indicative of its attitude to primary industry as a whole. As I said, primary industry is still one of our main trade exporters and major income earners at a time when we have a parlous balance of trade problem. At one stage the Prime Minister went to the Bundaberg area and suggested that sugar growers should change from growing sugar cane to growing vegetables. Honourable senators know how well that went over. That conversion has occurred in some areas, but we run the risk of flooding the market with vegetables and nobody winning. That was the Prime Minister's immediate reaction to the problems he saw there. His abysmal lack of knowledge of the industry and its problems is now well and truly on the record. I venture to suggest that if he returns to north Queensland it would certainly not want to be for the purpose of talking to the sugar growers. They do not want to hear all his promises again. He should go with his friend the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) and do some game fishing. The only time he will get any enjoyment in north Queensland is if he goes off-shore and catches a fish or two.
—I suppose they would go in State Government boats.

—I should imagine that if he wanted to go fishing he would not pay for it himself but try to wheedle one of the few State Government boats. While I am on the subject, I should mention that the State Government should start buying boats because north Queensland is not well protected by the Australian defence forces. Now that Senator Button has mentioned it, there was the promise of extra patrol boats in Cairns. That promise has not come to fruition. Whichever way the Prime Minister goes, I think that he would be safer doing some marlin fishing off-shore than talking to sugar growers.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry in Queensland is not sitting still and resting on its laurels. The University of Queensland has done a lot of work to find other products for this most efficient industry. In conjunction with a small Queensland firm called Queensland Science and Technology, it is looking at two processes-one called sucrotech and the other called biowastech. I welcomed the answer by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, as I indicated to him yesterday, regarding the 150 per cent tax deductibility for research and development by private firms. I think that will help the further research and development of these two processes in Queensland.

Sucrotech provides ethanol from sugar. Biowastech turns sugar juice and waste or effluent from any of the production processes into high protein stock food. The firm Queensland Science and Technology, in considering the pricing, considers that with cross-subsidisation within these manufacturing processes-that is, the production of sucrose, fructose, ethanol and high protein starch food-ethanol could be produced on an economic basis.

One thing that the falling dollar has done for us-there has to be a brighter side to every dark situation-is to bring the price of fuel up to a level where the production of ethanol can become economical, and this could be the way out. With the methods developed by the University of Queensland the production of ethanol could be a great help to the sugar industry as well as to our balance of payments position.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the market?

—The market is what the Federal Government would like to make it at the time. Up to 20 per cent ethanol could be added to petrol without having to change any of the settings on an engine. If we could produce ethanol at a price which is feasible, and we are getting to that because of the falling dollar and the increased price of fuel, providing the Federal Government does not want to put an excise on it-no country that is producing ethanol in the world today has put government excise on it-it has been worked out, using the sucrotech and biowastech processing methods, that we could return to the producers $20 per tonne of cane produced.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the industry is not sitting still and crying. All it wants is the same treatment that is meted out to everybody else in this country. It wants recognition of the way it has subsidised the consumer in Australia, and it also wants help. I welcome the announcement of the Minister yesterday of the 150 per cent tax deductibility for research and development because it will help these small firms. If we can get these things on line the sugar industry will probably have a brighter outlook than at present, certainly more than it has under the Hawke Labor Government. I formally move:

At end of motion add ', but the Senate notes with great concern the plight of the industry generally and the communities dependent on the industry because of the failure of the Hawke Government to honour its pre-election promises to assist the depressed sugar industry'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Sugar Agreement Bill 1985 is a relatively innocuous Bill. It deals with the ability to import into Australia the types of sugars which will not in any way affect the viability of our sugar industry, and it is accepted by the industry as being a reasonable proposition. However, the Bill covers only this minor change when we should be discussing the much more widespread problems that the sugar industry in Australia is facing today. It is Australia's second most valuable export crop and its fourth largest agricultural export earner. It is an extremely valuable industry, an industry, one would have thought, which would have been a high priority for the Government in terms of any legislative program.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collard, in his speech, essentially said that the problems in the sugar industry were the fault of the Hawke Government. I think that is vastly simplistic. The Government has very little to do with the problems that the industry faces and they certainly do not stem totally or in large part from the management of the Australian Labor Party Government. My problem with the Labor Government is that it has not done anything to confront the problems that are there, but it is not the source of those problems. The source is essentially outside Australia's control. One of the problems is the failure of the international sugar agreement of 1972 because the European Economic Community was never a party to that agreement. The two year extension, after the agreement expired in 1983, failed essentially because the United States of America was not in a position to continue as a party to the agreement, particularly in regard to import quotas that it imposed at that time. In effect, that amounted to a withdrawal of the United States-a very large part of the market-from that international agreement. The sugar industry then went into a rapid decline.

The extraordinary situation is that until three years ago the Queensland National Party State Government was urging growers to increase production, a situation which I found incredible at the time. I expressed that view in speeches I made in the Senate as far back as 1981 and which were recorded in Hansard. One of the first speeches I made was on this very subject. At that time sugar was commanding its highest price ever on the export market. But to read that price as being a long term operation for the sugar industry was to live in a fool's paradise. One could see the problems of the rising stocks, particularly the overproduction of beet in the EEC. Given the fact that on an average beet production would average at least two good crops out of every four, we could see that from 1981 onwards we were heading towards a massive world overproduction, and that is what we have now. We have something like 100 million tonnes and, of course, world consumption does not meet that. In fact, it has never met anything like that. In a market situation, with massive oversupply and consumption not increasing, we are going to run into problems. But that is not the only difficulty. The problem is very much in parallel with people looking at the problems in education, forgetting that between the good old days and now television has been invented.

We now have a different international situation in relation to the consumption of sugar. Corn derivatives in the United States now constitute 36 per cent of the sweetener market, particularly in soft drinks and the processing of food. The artificial sweetener component has to be taken into account in any understanding of the international sugar situation. We cannot put aside those developments and expect to continue to sell our sugar, high quality though it may be, to an ever diminishing international market. We knew that three, four, five years ago under the Fraser Government, which took absolutely no action, and the Hawke Government has not taken any either. Two moves have to be made; one of which has to be a short term move to support the sugar growing areas in Australia, which extend basically from Grafton in New South Wales to Mossman in north Queensland. The interesting thing is that all of the coastal areas between those towns depend almost totally on those regional sugar economies. Without sugar those towns cannot exist. Town after town on the Queensland coast relies basically on a sugar economy.

I think the unemployment situation illustrates the problem we are running into. Between September 1983 and September 1984 there was a 3 per cent decrease as a whole throughout Australia following some of the successful economic moves made by the Hawke Government. In the sugar districts there was a 16 per cent increase. That is the difference, and that is what is occurring. Translating that into people and costs, we are looking at in the order of 30,000 people being directly employed in the sugar industry in Australia. Given the normal multipliers in our economy-certainly those multipliers work more in the sugar industry because, as I have explained, it is very much a regional economy-based industry-we would be looking at in the order of 200,000 people being dependent on the sugar industry.

If we take 12,000 people from that 200,000-that is not a large percentage, it is not the percentage growth that occurred from September 1983 to September 1984-the cost of those 12,000 people being without employment in the sugar industry is $120m. I put that figure of $120m for two reasons: Firstly, the Government is quibbling about putting money into the industry in the short term. It will be putting money into the industry, all right, but it will be going to the unemployed in those areas to the tune of $120m at least within the next 12 months. It would seem to me to make eminent sense if, instead of spending $120m in unemployment benefits, we spent one-tenth of that in keeping those people in employment in the short term. Senator Collard has already explained that the industry has put in far more than that since it began operating in Australia. The export price we have managed to receive for sugar has propped up the domestic sugar price, certainly since 1948 and probably before that. Only in recent years and only on a couple of occasions that I recall within that intermediate period has the reverse been the case.

So the sugar industry has a very good moral claim, and I suggest that it has a very strong financial claim for that short term assistance. However, no government will put that type of money into a short term operation unless it can be assured that the longer term situation will be brighter. It just does not make sense-it certainly does not make economic sense-to prop up any industry in the short term if, in the longer term, it does not have bright prospects. Instead, we must seek some type of rationalisation for the industry. After all, that has been suggested on and off by a variety of people, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). A restructuring of the industry has been suggested. Various industry groups have suggested driving people out of the industry, and there have been a number of other suggestions, all based on the notion that the industry has nowhere to go. I dispute that the industry has nowhere to go. The industry could have an exceptionally bright future, but it cannot have a future which is a continuation of the past, as it were. That is no longer operative. Not only are trade associations such as the EEC and countries such as the United States developing alternative usages or creating excess stocks but also a number of our traditional markets are moving to self-sufficiency. There are a whole host of reasons why we are never likely to move into that boom situation again.

I do not believe that the sugar market is cyclical. It was in the past but it is no longer and will not be in the future. Those who keep proposing the notion of a cyclical operation in the sugar industry are just not looking at the facts as we have to face in today's world. Where is the sugar industry in Australia to go? It has to look at alternative usages. That is the only way out; otherwise we have to go along with the doomsday predictions and wind down the industry.

In a speech I made on 15 October 1981 I raised the problems of this industry. I remind honourable senators that that was when Mr Fraser and the Liberal and National parties were still in government. I raised the problem of a researcher at Queensland University. He is the same researcher who is responsible for the types of operations Senator Collard was suggesting today. He berated the Labor Government for doing nothing much about the research situation. I raised this matter in 1981 with the Liberal-National Party Government and it did absolutely nothing. Let us hear about the kettle calling the pot black. At that time I raised the problem of Professor Doelle's research money being withdrawn and the fact that when he asked why that research grant was being withdrawn he received a letter stating, basically: 'We do not have the money to tell you why your research grant has been withdrawn'. The rundown of research grants by the Fraser Government was horrific, and that has not stopped under the Hawke Government.

The reason I raise this matter is that Professor Doelle is now in a situation of having some support from private industry to get a pilot plant operational for his sucrotech process. Essentially, the usefulness of that process is not simply in its ethanol production. It is an exceptionally efficient way of producing ethanol. There is interest in this process also because it is able to join together the ethanol and the fructose operation-the high sugar concentrate. If one looks particularly at the soft drink industry to see the type of product we are looking at, the dramatic effect of the introduction of such a technique into the Australian industry will be apparent. I will come to that point in a moment because there was an interjection by Senator Button or Senator Collard and I think it is important.

Let us say that we can use those products. How much sugar cane would we need to grow to be able to satisfy, for example, Queensland's need-just one State-in a 20 per cent mix of ethanol and petrol? We would need to grow twice the current Australian crop. I think that is staggering. It means that in a research development we have the possibility for using any amount of Australian sugar, moving to open up production on the Ord, and actually using the Burdekin Dam for its original intention. People can raise the argument that it is an untried technology, an untried method, and indeed it is. I am not saying that it will work and I am not giving a 100 per cent guarantee that it will work.

This industry is important to Australia. How much money are we prepared to put up to test that importance? What would be a reasonable amount of money? Would it be the amount of money we are spending on the yachting challenge in Perth? Would $8m be a reasonable amount? A figure of $8m seems to be a reasonable proposition. If we had put up $8m when I first raised this mater in 1981 that process would have been well and truly tried and tested and could have been in commercial production, if it had proved successful. As it is, we still have only about $1m available, not from government sources but from private industry, and we still have at least a two-year lead time, as well as probably one growing season on top of that.

The person who has worked on this research is loaded down with teaching duties at the Department of Microbiology at the University of Queensland. That is what we really call using Australia's inventiveness and talents to the full, is it not? The very person who could now be working full time on the best possible long term outlet for our sugar in this country cannot even get down to research and has not got the dollars to be able at least to try it out. One would have thought that in terms of venture capital it would be worth putting that money in just to test it out and just to see whether it worked, because the results could be so staggering for us.

Fructose, in terms of its use, is no problem at all. We could even export it. There are no problems in terms of any development we might have in that area. However, in terms of ethanol production there is a difficulty. In Australia we are not geared to its usage in the quantities we have been talking about here; certainly the quantities I have been talking about. I acknowledge that fact. Here in Australia we are now moving to the use of lead free petrol. Lead free petrol is low octane petrol. The simplest, most efficient-certainly the most cost-efficient-way of moving that petrol back to high octane is by adding ethanol to it. That is the simplest way of doing it. It is a tried method used in other countries. No new understanding is needed for that. However, in Australia we are doing the opposite. We are re-gearing our motor vehicles to take care of the lead free petrol instead of looking at the alternative of developing our own ethanol industry.

I admit that until recently it has not been cost-efficient. I am not claiming that it was. Ethanol production is one of the things that the Australian Democrats have been promoting very strongly. We have always acknowledged the problem of costs. That problem of cost is no longer there. We are now confronted with the fact that we cannot move our sugar and that there are enormously rising costs in the sugar industry. We are confronted with the destruction of regional economies throughout this country and the consequent enormous cost to the Government not only of export dollars but also of additional expenditure in the social security budgets. Therefore, I think if one considers that package one is absolutely staggered that we have not put money into research for alternatives.

The proposition I put forward in 1981-I remember being supported at the time by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan)-was in terms of the absolute need for money to be spent on research. I think I have now been able to show where, in one case at least, that money, if it had been forthcoming under the Fraser Government in 1981, could have gone and how it would have put Australia, and a large number of people in Australia, in a far more viable position. To do that we have to believe in our own capacity. We have to believe in our own people and put money into research in the hope that it will bring long term benefits to this country.

Politically it is better to throw a few dollars here and there as bribes for electoral purposes. I admit that that is great. In the short term a dollar here and a dollar there might buy a few votes. Ultimately Australia will continue on the downward slide. All governments and all political parties have to call a halt to that short term operation. We must all now agree that unless we put money into research this country does not have a bright economic future or the possibility of maintaining the standard of living which we all now enjoy. It is as simple as that.

The amounts of money necessary for the process I am talking about are absolute peanuts in terms of the national Budget. To establish a complete research facility, to release the researchers who would be necessary and to bring quickly the necessary fermenting plant on stream would take approximately $8m. That is the amount we have offered to Western Australia for the America's Cup challenge. I put to the Senate that if I had only $8m and I had to choose I certainly know where I would want to spend that money. I would want to spend it in the long term interests of this country. I would want to spend it on the people of this country and on an industry that has given so much to this country. I believe that the sugar industry deserves this short term support and the research funds to look at the possible alternative usages. It deserves that type of support from this Government. It deserves that support from any government.

I believe the dereliction of duty not only of this Government but previous governments in this area has led us to where we are today. Blame, once apportioned, might be very fulfilling but not terribly useful. I believe we now need to go forward. I believe this Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) must, as a matter of urgency, see what type of government support can be provided for testing not only the ethanol fructose method at Queensland University but every other possible outlet for our sugar. It is only with that type of drive, energy and immediate support that the sugar industry in this country can look forward. I do not believe the sugar industry should have to put up with threats of having to scale itself down, farmers having to get off the land or regional economies being wound back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Sugar Agreement Bill 1985 I must say that the sugar industry has been, and I hope always will be, a great Australian industry. However, it is an industry in trouble and, as a big industry, it is in big trouble. The aspect which I wish to look at concerns the fact that the problems of the sugar industry are symptomatic of problems in the production industries generally and in the food industries in particular. That is what really matters. The importance of the sugar industry to Australia has to be clear to all. We have had a listing of the various problems that the industry faces and we have had some suggestions from previous speakers as to what might be done. I am not sure, having listened to those speakers, that that is where the problem lies. One honourable senator implied that it was a socialist problem. I do not necessarily go along with that. I think it is a social problem. I will come back to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: We must face the reality that in all developed countries the consumption of sugar in sugar form is declining and that it is likely to continue to do so over the following years. At present the undeveloped and underdeveloped countries are increasing their consumption of sugar. Not only are they increasing sugar consumption but they are increasing sugar production. There is a drive around the world for countries to become self-sufficient not only in sugar but also in a variety of other products. Australia, incidentally, has also been successful in that we have undoubtedly become the major producer in the world of equipment used for the production of sugar. We have become so good at it that we have even sold our equipment to all of our competitors. We are making them far more able to compete with us on a price basis than they ever were before, or than they ever would have been without our equipment.

Until 10 years ago, or perhaps less than that, it would have been absolutely unthinkable that the sugar industry could have faced the crisis that it is now facing. We have the problems of declining consumption, overproduction and lack of international marketing. The point I return to is that the present problems are absolutely mammoth. But the history of the sugar industry over a period has been very good. It has been well managed and well organised and, in regard to marketing and security, other primary industries have a very considerable amount that they can learn from the sugar industry. Governments, incidentally, should also see the applicability of this to other industries.

The prohibition of the import of foreign destabilising sugar has been of great interest and great value to the sugar industry and its development, stability and profitability in Australia. I hope that this Government and a future Liberal government will also see the applicability to other industries of what has been appropriate for the sugar industry. Australia generally needs to consider the fundamental needs of its productive sector and the food producers in particular. More and more overseas countries are producing food and more and more of them are reserving their local markets for their own producers. Australia must surely be the only country in the world that is watching its food producing industries gradually decline and run the risk of disappearing.

If Australia has a desire to remain self-sufficient in food production, it must follow this policy through in regard to a range of other food products. I am not talking about questions of efficiency, locational suitability, aptitude, state of mind or anything like that. We need to remember that in Australia we can produce a range of food products as economically and efficiently as any other country in the world. We should be doing it so that at least we can feed our own people. I will mention one or two industries that at present are worth considering. What about products such as asparagus, mushrooms, peas and beans, avocadoes, dried fruit, citrus fruit and citrus juice, or berry fruits? We are just watching those industries disappear from Australia. What worries me is that the dairy industry is following and now the sugar industry is following. It is all very well to consider propping up the sugar industry at this stage. But we are providing aspirin, and that is all. I believe that the whole problem is much more deep seated and requires a lot of attention other than just providing aspirin.

Australia simply cannot get to the stage of being dependent upon other countries to provide its food. Every time we bring in products that destabilise Australian production, we lose something Australian forever. We usually lose Australian jobs, Australian capital investment and specialist knowledge. While the number of people involved in the sugar industry seems to vary according to who is speaking, the figures that were provided to me showed that there were approximately 6,000 sugar farmers and about 100,000 people directly employed in the industry. If we let the situation get out of hand by allowing the industry to disperse and disappear, what will happen to those people, that capital, that knowledge and all the things that go with it?

I willingly acknowledge that support can lead, and in some cases has led, to industry inefficiencies. But it does not have to do so, and with reasonable planning and reasonable management it will not. Industry generally, when confronted with circumstances of this nature, is perfectly capable of facing reality. In return for industry maintenance it can operate at a price and at a production level that is appropriate. Surely, the producers of food in Australia deserve national support. I think it was in today's Age that I noticed a large advertisement bearing the name N. L. Gallagher, asking the Victorian Government to support the producers of food, namely milk, in Victoria. I believe that at last we are on the right track. If we could get people to support the producers of food in the same way as they support the people who are on wages, we would have no problem in this area. But at present it is left to the producers of food to balance the national budget. It seems that the Government expects the producers of food to be the people who control the degree of inflation, the cost of living, or both.

I was interested to see in one of the annual reports that were before the Senate yesterday a graph which showed that in 1973 food had a price index of 138. By 1984 food had risen to 404-an increase of 292 per cent. In 1973 wages had an index of 175, but by 1984 had risen to 750-a rise of 428 per cent. In other words, the index for wages, which are a direct cost in production, rose 68 per cent faster than the index for food. Of course that will have a destabilising effect on production costs; of course it makes us less competitive with overseas producers; and of course it reduces the profitability of the people in Australia who are trying to feed the people of this country. But one cannot control costs in one area without controlling costs in the other. That is why I say that it is a social cost and not a socialist cost. The country as a whole has allowed our wage system to get ahead of our productivity system. Until we can bring those two systems back together, the food producing industries of Australia, and any other productive industry, must be set to decline.

As one who has a minor involvement in food production, I do have some knowledge of the business, the people involved and their problems. They deserve to be paid an appropriate return for what they produce. In return, of course, they must apply appropriate constraints to production. This is, of course, noticeably absent in the European Economic Community and in other countries in which, in many cases, the minute any backing or support is given by government, production goes up and a surplus situation ensues. We do not want that to happen. I will be looking to the Government to produce similar legislation in support of other food producers. I am not asking for anything that is not appropriate for the sugar industry to be done for similar industries. I was pleased to note that the Governor-General's Speech specifically stated that the Government was committed to the 'achievement of high social goals of equity and fairness'. As the Government has made that pledge in the Governor-General's address, I certainly trust that it will be carried through to the food producers of Australia generally and, in this case, to the sugar industry.

I support the legislation. I trust that it will be just one of the ways in which the Government will seek to look after the sugar industry. I noticed that the Governor-General in his Speech referred to the Government's plan to 'restructure and revitalise the industry'. I trust that this legislation is one of the methods that the Government will use to start on its program but I concede that it will not in itself put the sugar industry right. The point that I wish to make most strongly is that the sugar industry's problems are symptomatic of the problems in all the productive industries, in particular the food industries. I believe that if we are to restore these industries to a reasonable level it will have to be done on the basis that they get a reasonable return for reasonable production.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister told the sugar industry that he was not prepared to grant any assistance to the industry until after the sugar growers organisations completed a review of the industry. ANSWER.PARA: It is a long-established principle, as I understand it, in intelligence exchanges between countries that a recipient of intelligence undertakes not to pass that material to any third country without the authorisation of the originator. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HOME HELP PROGRAM FOR VETERANS IN TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. News reports from Tasmania indicate that the Department of Veterans' Affairs is having considerable difficulty in negotiating reasonable conditions relating to the transfer of staff from the formerly Commonwealth funded community employment home help program for veterans in Tasmania to the State's home help scheme. What is the present situation with the transfer? Will the 10 women concerned be assured of further employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that there are some difficulties associated with the transfer of the initiative begun by the Government in respect of the innovative home help scheme which was begun under the community employment program and administered by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis. That scheme came to an end because it had a limited duration. However, because of the success of the scheme, it was made a Budget item. This means that what began as an experiment is now part of the ongoing programs of the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

ANSWER.PARA: Negotiations have been conducted with all the States with a view to the States taking over the operation of the scheme and the Department of Veterans' Affairs buying the services from the State organisations. A measure of agreement has been reached in all States with the exception of Tasmania, where numerous conferences have been held since we began the process of having the matters dealt with in a decentralised way within the State organisations. One meeting was held in November and another one in January. A problem that emerged was that the State could not provide the same level of service. Tasmania refused to give a guarantee in respect of the future employment of these women who had been specially selected and are currently employed under the CEP funding.

The Commonwealth is happy to continue funding to the service as it has proved to be very beneficial to veterans. The service is subject to cost-benefit analysis and provides employment as well as assisting veterans to stay in their homes. Of course, the Commonwealth is not interested in establishing a separate organisation to that which is already being provided by the States for non-veterans. However, the appropriate Tasmanian Minister has said that legislative constraints would bar any direct transfer of women currently employed by the Commonwealth to the State Public Service. One of the matters of principle upon which the Commonwealth is insisting in its discussions with the States is that the women be transferred from Commonwealth to State employment so that what was begun as an experiment will result in permanent employment for women who have carried out their tasks in every circumstance very admirably.

We are insisting in the negotiations with the Tasmanian Government that those principles, which have been accepted in all other States, should apply and that, therefore, the Tasmanian government should take legislative action to ensure that that process is continued in Tasmania as, indeed, it is in all the other States. We recognise that a Tasmanian Act makes it difficult for such persons to be transferred. Nevertheless, there are arrangements under which personnel employed by States have been transferred to the Commonwealth. That principle should be applied in this case. We believe that the Tasmanian Government has a responsibility to find a solution to the problem and to provide continuing employment for those who were involved in the initial scheme.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I have seen the figures; otherwise Senator Aulich would not have asked me the question. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures deal with new fixed capital expenditure and reveal that there was a solid recovery in business investment in the December quarter. I notice that there are no more grins on the faces of those on the other side of the chamber. They are against an increase in fixed capital investment. There are gloomy faces on the other side.
—How do they compare with the figures for June 1983?

—I am coming to that, Senator. Do not get excited. New fixed capital investment in real terms rose by nearly 4 per cent to be 9.4 per cent above the levels recorded in the December quarter 1983. Investment in new building and structures in the year to December 1984 increased by 16.8 per cent in real terms. The figures for manufacturing investment are also heartening, to those on this side of the chamber at least.
—How do they compare with the figures for 1929?
—They are very heartening and if Senator Lewis listened to them even he might be encouraged. Investment in manufacturing rose in December 1984 to be 12.4 per cent above the December quarter of 1983.
—What about the June quarter of 1983?

—Senator Chaney keeps asking about the June quarter of 1983. The June quarter of 1983 is terribly important to him. I feel I should reiterate that the December figure of 12.4 per cent was above that for the previous year. The improvement in the December quarter figures is reflected in expectations for 1984-85. Investment in manufacturing is expected to be 18 per cent above the 1983-84 level. The December quarter preliminary survey also features 1985-86 expectations data and these point to a substantial rise in new investment of 24 per cent for 1985-86 over 1983-84.

ANSWER.PARA: The figures on the investment front are good news for most people. The Government will maintain the direction in economic and industry policy which has helped to produce those figures. Investment figures are a reflection of improving confidence in the Australian economy generally. That process has been going on since at least June 1983, which is of so much concern to Senator Chaney, because that was when he was still recovering from the election result of 1983. This country has been recovering for two or three years now.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures are still lower than they were in June 1983.

—So what? If Senator Chaney wants to refer to the 1982 figures he is welcome to do so. Perhaps I should remind him that when his Government went out of power there was rising inflation, rising unemployment, rising interest rates and declining investment. Perhaps Senator Chaney has to be reminded of those figures because they are very important in terms of what has happened since. I can understand the gloom on the other side of the chamber about these matters because just as members of the Opposition are concerned to undermine the ANZUS alliance by the silly questions that have been raised here today, so they are concerned at this stage to undermine rising confidence in the Australian economy. Of course, their efforts to undermine these things are very much influenced by declining ratings in opinion polls in respect of the Opposition's performance.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VISITS TO AUSTRALIA BY NAVAL VESSELS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Defence. I refer the Minister to Premier Wran's concession, now somewhat belated, that the question of visits by naval vessels to the port of Sydney is a matter for the Federal Government. Does the Victorian Premier, Mr Cain, also concede that the matter is one for the Federal Government and the State governments should not place restrictions on such visits? In view of the fact that no nuclear-powered ships or ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons have visited Victoria since 1982, will the Minister, on behalf of the Government, give an unequivocal guarantee that such vessels will have access to the port of Melbourne, subject, of course, to the normal safety guidelines to which he referred the other day in answer to a question from me?

—The Victorian Premier has repeatedly made it clear publicly that he accepts totally that the Federal Government has constitutional power to control visits by nuclear warships to Australian ports. Victoria has been declared by the State Government to be a nuclear free State, but only in relation to those matters over which the State has constitutional authority. I am sure that any question that might arise in the future about a visit of a nuclear ship in Victorian waters or Victorian ports would be resolved by reference to those principles which Mr Cain has acknowledged.

—I ask a supplementary question. In view of that information, does the Federal Government concede that, in light of the attitude of the Victorian Government, there should be a discouragement of visits by nuclear-powered ships or ships capable of carrying nuclear weapons to the port of Melbourne?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

—Has the attention of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women been drawn to the formation of the Sisterhood is Global Institute late last year? Has that Institute outlined the degradation of women in such countries as Iran, where virgins are raped before execution; in China, where the Government concedes an epidemic of drownings and other murders of girl babies; and the Soviet Union, where the average woman has about a dozen abortions because of lack of contraception? What is the Australian Government doing through international forums to protest about the subjugation and degradation of women? Will the Government find out which of the various degradations of which I have spoken are the policy of foreign governments and consider appropriate action analogous to our dealing with the apartheid regime in South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that an article in the Age of 16 February this year headed 'When women's liberation is a matter of life and death' raised allegations of violence against feminists in countries such as Iran and also other issues mentioned in Senator Tate's question, including issues in China, Russia, and I am advised, Aboriginal child mortality in Australia. The article draws upon a book entitled Sisterhood is Global which has not yet been published in Australia and which, I am advised, appears to contain a mixture of truth and dubious allegations against governments. Its theme is that women's global vision is the politics of the twenty-first century. Clearly, its aim is to raise the consciousness of governments which will be participating in the Nairobi End of Decade for Women Conference and to have those matters addressed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Institute to which Senator Tate referred in this question was established to consider programs over the United Nations Decade for Women and to present a case for feminist action to advance into areas where governments would not be prepared to go. In response to Senator Tate's question about the attitude of the Australian Government to such issues, the Australian Government strongly supports international initiatives to raise the status of women and, of course, we are an active participant in the Commission on the Status of Women which is the focal point in the United Nations system for the examination and discussion of status of women issues. We are, of course, active supporters of the other United Nations human rights bodies which examine allegations of torture and similar human rights violations.

Justice Evatt is the Australian expert on the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. This Committee examines breaches of the Convention. Next week Australia will have a three-woman delegation attending the Commission on the Status of Women which is currently preparing for the End of Decade for Women Conference to be held in Nairobi in July. Following that exercise, more information about the allegations and the action that the Australian Government will be able to take will be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the paper from which she quoted.
—Yes.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows his answer to a question by Senator Aulich regarding his selective use of figures on business investment. Is it a fact that, as reported, last week the Prime Minister embarked on a ring-around of leading exporters, pleading with them to repatriate funds to prop up the feeble Australian dollar? Did he consider that one man's plea, even from one so high as the Prime Minister, could influence international market forces, or was this just another example of what has become painfully familiar to most Australians; that is Mr Hawke's being naive and panicking and stumbling in the face of a national problem? Does not the plight of the dollar and Mr Hawke's pathetic attempts to rectify it make a farce of his acceptance of an invitation to tell Canada how it should be done?

—Order! Once again, I remind honourable senators to keep their questions as brief as possible. I ask Ministers to do likewise in respect of their answers. I call the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the Prime Minister engaged in a ring-around of exporters, as Senator Walters suggested. I will find out. I would not regard it as normal if he did. It is probably much better than the previous Prime Minister's habit of ringing newspaper proprietors in the middle of the night. I would think it is a far more productive activity. I will find out and obtain an answer to the question. Insofar as Senator Walters's question was predicated on a reference to my selective use of figures, there is nothing selective about the economic recovery which has taken place under this Government. It is continuing, and the investment figures are a growing and strengthening sign of confidence in that recovery. There is nothing selective about that at all.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Chaney's interjection in relation to the June 1983 figures, to which Senator Walters perhaps was referring, insofar as there was a flutter up in investments in June 1983, I expect that reflects only a sigh of relief by the investment community that we had finally got rid of the Fraser Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he has seen the claim by Dr Denis Mackey that repetition strain injury was invented two years ago as a 'bit of a joke', that 'aches and pains of everyday life have been translated into RSI and floated to a gullible community as a workers compensation claim', and that 'the myth of RSI is at present a stage of amusement for the medical profession'? Does the Minister agree that Dr Mackey is just being mischievous and is in effect accusing many general practitioners and specialists of misdiagnosing, and that such an attitude by a member of the medical profession could inhibit sufferers of RSI from seeking early treatment at the risk of permanent injury? Is it possible for the Minister to estimate how many other doctors in the community may be seeing RSI victims and dismissing their complaints as malingering?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no way of quantifying the information Senator Coates asked for in the latter part of his question, nor have I any information from the Minister for Health on that matter. I will see whether there is any information of that type available, but I doubt very much that there is. Dr Mackey is well known to Senator Coates, me and a few other people. He is many things, but an expert on RSI he is not, although I suppose he is entitled to his views, like anyone else. He is a prolific writer of letters to newspapers on all sorts of subjects, from political philosophy to Medicare and economics. His pet hates in life seem to be, in some order of magnitude: Public servants, the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia, and the Australian Medical Association. He is quite catholic in his interests and dislikes.
—Catholic?

—I apologise, Senator Tate, I was not referring to your religion. I think therefore that not too many members of the medical profession will take Dr Mackey's letter very seriously. As Senator Coates says, it could have unfortunate effects in the treatment of the people who have what has come to be known as repetition strain injury.

ANSWER.PARA: Among Dr Mackey's remarks was the statement that RSI was just an Australian phenomenon. In fact, although the incidence seems to be very high in this country, particularly in the Public Service, there is a substantial body of literature on this syndrome in Europe, in medical journals in the United States of America and, of course, in Australia. At the moment an Australian Public Service task force, headed by Mr Des Linehan, is in the process of hearing submissions from various government departments, professional organisations, individuals and others such as unions, on this very subject. All the indications, I believe, are that RSI is a widespread condition, not only in Australia but also overseas, in which physical, psychological, management and ergonometric factors play their part. Quite clearly, whatever the cause, it is a major occupational health problem in Australia. The Government and the Department of Health are aware of the issues involved. We are taking steps to examine the problem in depth as a matter of priority. I suggest that the best thing Dr Mackey can do to back up his views is to offer to give evidence to the task force of the Public Service Board. Any evidence he has can be examined by that body and we can see whether he has anything useful to contribute.

I make the final comment that it has been a general belief in the medical profession that propositions of the type Dr Mackey has put are best put forward in a scientific way and in a way that can be examined by the medical profession and others who have to deal with the problem. In most cases it is believed that seeking publicity in what is euphemistically called the popular Press or through letters to newspapers is neither scientific nor sensible. I can only assume that what Dr Mackey is up to is what he is often up to, and that is to get his name on the front page of as many newspapers as possible in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I seek clarification of the Government's decision not to provide the logistic support requested by the United States of America for its MX testing, despite the deterrent importance of the MX. Are we to understand from the Government that until the first week of February it was the view of the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence, and the Ambassador for Disarmament that the nature of Australian support requested by the US was such that rejection of the request would remove Australia's credibility with our ally, especially with regard to disarmament and arms control? More specifically, why then was it that during the first week of February the Prime Minister unilaterally decided to reject that request? I say 'reject' notwithstanding the fact that the US was finally forced to withdraw the request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not remember the exact dates to which Senator Teague referred in his question but, yes, it is true that four Ministers in the Government decided, at an early stage, that the agreement entered into by the Fraser Government to provide logistic support for the MX tests should be carried out, subject to some modification of the terms of that agreement. I think it is important that we understand what were the terms of the agreement as entered into by the Fraser Government. The only public announcement about the terms of that agreement was made by Mr Sinclair on a PM program one night, when he was asked about the agreement. He said: 'Yes, we agreed to that. It was like arranging to play tennis. We said: ''Let's have a game some time. We will fix the time and place at a later stage''.' The agreement was as sloppy as that. It was just like agreeing to play tennis, in the words of the former Minister of Defence in the Fraser Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that four Ministers agreed to that. The Prime Minister did not unilaterally change his mind, as suggested in Senator Teague's question. He decided that in consultation with a number of colleagues. All this is a matter of public record so I do not know why Senator Teague, unless he belongs to the ranks of Senator Withers and never reads newspapers, regurgitates these things during Question Time in the Senate. Insofar as it was a unilateral rejection, as it was put, the facts are clear. By the time the Prime Minister reached the United States, the United States Government had reached a decision on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Face-saving-that is all that was.
—Face-saving on whose part? Either on the part of the United States Government--
—Your Prime Minister.

—Is that so? So the United States of Government went out of its way to save the Prime Minister's face? That is all right. So what? I doubt whether the United States Government would go out of its way to save the face of the Opposition of this country. When the Prime Minister arrived in the United States a statement was made by Mr Shultz on the United States Government's attitude, and that statement has been read into the Senate Hansard. They are the facts of the matter, and I would have thought that everybody would have been aware of them, except perhaps Senator Teague.

—I ask a supplementary question. Putting aside the Minister's personal references, because this is a matter of importance. I ask for clarification. When it meant overriding the long term security of Australians, by what process did the Prime Minister assess the representativeness of the minority views being put to him by his Party along these lines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the question contains a value judgment that the decision overrides the long term security of Australians. That is the view to which Senator Teague is entitled. It is a view of the ANZUS alliance which was consistently put by Liberal governments over a number of years-that is, if one does anything which is different from the United States, if one advocates any policy which is different from that advocated by the United States, one is in breach, as it were, of the treaty of friendship which this country has with the United States. That attitude to the United States alliance cost 500 Australian lives in Vietnam.

ANSWER.PARA: I can remember being in the Senate when honourable senators now sitting on the other side of the chamber were arguing with vehemence when in government that it would do something for the people of Afghanistan if we boycotted the Moscow Olympic Games. Does nobody read the newspapers now? Is nobody on the Opposition side concerned about the people of Afghanistan? What did that action do?

They are the sorts of things in respect of which there is a possibility to exert a slightly different view from that expressed over time by the United States Government. To say in question, as Senator Teague said, that we are overriding the long term security of this country is not a view which this Government does not accept and which Mr Shultz and the President of the United States do not accept.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COSTS INCURRED BY TWO SENATE SELECT COMMITTEES

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is addressed to you. I must preface my question by saying that I have been approached by a number of constituents concerning the costs involved with the Senate Select Committee on the Conduct of a Judge and the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge. Are you in a position to be able to provide the Senate with the information which has been requested of me?
—I have been supplied by the Department of the Senate with some figures which I do not have immediately available, but I shall obtain them and give the honourable senator a reply.

—Can the Minister for Community Services confirm a report in the Australian Financial Review of 6 February that the Government was considering a special interdepartmental committee report on occupational superannuation which indicated that it had reached substantial agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions on the extension of superannuation as part of the forthcoming wage case? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, an interdepartmental committee was looking at occupational superannuation. Yes, there is a report which the Government has been looking at. I did not see the report in the Financial Review. I certainly know nothing of any agreement with the ACTU concerning the extension of occupational superannuation as part of any wage case or wage settlement. I will seek an answer to that question from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the matter of tabling such a report, it is not the custom to do so. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs. In the report of the Kirby Committee to Review Productivity and Innovation Programs, which is considering labour market programs, it is stated that although the number of community youth support scheme projects now exceeds the number of Commonwealth Employment Service officers, the distribution of CYSS projects is inequitable. These people are very confused about their role and constantly anxious about their future. The report recommended that they be developed into a new Australian youth service. Can the Minister say whether the Government is considering an alternative to CYSS? If so, what form will it take and how will it be established?

—I am not able to comment fully on the detail requested by Senator Foreman. However, the Government is conducting a thorough examination of the recommendations of the Kirby report, including, particularly, the proposals for training and upgrading of training facilities and schemes. An announcement will be made about that in the not too distant future. I assume that the examination of the Kirby report will include an examination of some of the difficulties with CYSS projects to which Senator Foreman has averted in his question. I will seek further clarification from the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Youth Affairs and provide Senator Foreman with a more detailed answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Given that Australia's monetary supply is running substantially in excess of budget, a heavy trade imbalance, a burgeoning Budget deficit, a lower exchange rate, high government borrowings and average weekly earnings increases running in excess of those of our major trading partners, does the Minister expect inflation to rise in the medium term? On what rationale does the Treasurer base his conclusion that interest rates, after payment of current tax obligations, will not rise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear the early part of that question, but I think I got the substance of it satisfactorily. There are references to the current account deficit, the Budget deficit, the falling value of the dollar and so on. The bottom line of the question seemed to be whether, as a result of all these factors, inflation was likely to rise or remain stable in the medium term. Of course, it is undeniable that a sustained fall in the value of the Australian dollar will have some effect on the consumer price index, although, as I explained the other day, import prices are a minor component of the CPI regimen and even changes in import prices are not normally entirely passed on to the CPI.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the question is no, inflation is not likely to rise in the medium term because, by April, we will have gone through a 12-month period in which here has been no increase in wages. It is expected that there will be an increase of the order of 2 1/2 per cent in April. That will have a far more significant impact on the consumer price index and, to the degree that the nominal interest rate is not influenced by the CPI, therefore no effect on interest rates.

Senator Watson seems to be labouring under the misconception that, because the price of the Australian dollar has fallen, necessarily interest rates will increase and has clearly failed to understand a major reason for the decision to float the Australian dollar; that is, with a floating dollar it will not be necessary to increase interest rates in order to protect the value of the currency.

In short, the outlook for the CPI and interest rates over the medium term-I do not think anybody can sensibly make predictions beyond the medium term-is that there are not likely to be any increases, as the Treasurer has said. Indeed, I would suggest that there is the possibility of some reductions, in marked contrast to a situation which prevailed when this Government came to office just under two years ago when inflation was in double figures, unemployment was in double figures, economic growth was negative and the country was in the midst of the deepest depression that it had known in the previous 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which refers to the recent concern over the acquired immune deficiency syndrome virus and the in vitro fertilisation program and the artificial insemination by donor program, is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is the Minister able to confirm that special precautions are now used to screen donor sperm and ova for AIDS? Can the Minister say what effect the AIDS dilemma will have on those frozen embryos already in storage which were developed from donor sperm? Are precise records kept so that tracing can occur of both the individual donor and where that donor's gametes are placed within either of the two programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some concern has been expressed over the possibility of the AIDS virus being transmitted through the in vitro fertilisation program and the artificial insemination by donor programs. A study in the United States of America of some 10,000 artificial inseminations by donors using frozen semen has found no cases of the transmission of AIDS by this route. Obviously the risk is there hypothetically but we do not think it is very high. Nevertheless, the medical profession and the various authorities have taken steps to develop safeguards.

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of precautions has varied between the States because of differences in their artificial insemination and in vitro fertilisation programs. It is also limited by the availability of the AIDS screening test from research teams. I cannot give details of the various steps that have been taken in each State, but, in general what happens is that donors of semen are being required to sign a declaration similar to that signed by blood donors, stating that they are not members of groups with a high risk of AIDS. Where the research teams are able to make tests for antibodies to the AIDS related virus available from their limited supplies, semen donors are also being screened by this method. The donor is screened again some months later before the semen is used. In some cases frozen semen donated before 1980, which can be presumed to be uncontaminated, is in fact used. Similar precautions are being instituted for donors of sperm in in vitro fertilisation programs. I understand that donor ova are not used in these programs. If donor embryos are used the donors will be screened for antibodies for AIDS. In all the in vitro fertilisation programs in this country precise records of donors are kept. So I believe that the precautions that have been taken in all the States are in fact rigorous in their attempts to ensure that this possible transmission of the virus will not occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of criticism concerning lengthy delays in the processing of proposals to the Foreign Investment Review Board, and does the Minister accept that such delays will lead to a reduction in the amount of foreign capital available to encourage development and provide much needed employment opportunities? Can the Minister say whether the reports of processing delays are fair and accurate, and if they are, what steps are being taken to facilitate speedier processing of those proposals? Will the Minister provide statistics showing the number of proposals put to the Foreign Investment Review Board over the past two years and the time it has taken to process these proposals?

—I will just sort out some of the factual confusion. This question, because it concerns the Foreign Investment Review Board, ought to have been addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, which is me as it was in the previous Parliament. I do not have any knowledge of recent complaints about delays but it is quite possible that there are complaints but without my being aware of them or of the length of time for which particular applications may have been held up. Senator Kilgariff suggested that some action should be taken to expedite the processing of these applications. I suppose that is not a bad idea, but I hope he is not suggesting that we should expedite foreign investment by the means employed by the former Chief Minister of the Territory he represents. This expedition of foreign investment included the expropriation of property and the illegal advancing of bridging finance by the Northern Government to the foreign beneficiary of the property which had been expropriated from the previous owner.

—Has the Minister for Resources and Energy seen the article by the political commentator Maximilian Walsh published in the Sydney Morning Herald last Monday, 25 February, which criticised the proposal to introduce a system of cash bidding for the allocation of petroleum exploration rights? Of the off-shore petroleum exploration areas released recently, how many are for work program bidding and how many will be awarded on the new cash bidding system? What are some of the difficulties encountered with the existing program bidding system? Will the introduction of the cash bidding system result in a reduction of funds available for petroleum exploration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the 14 exploration areas in the north-west Australia off-shore region that were released in February nine are for work program bidding and five are for cash bidding when the legislation is in place. The nine areas available for work program bidding are spread around the adjacent areas of Western Australia, the Northern Territory and the Ashmore and Cartier Islands. All of the remaining five areas released for cash bidding are in the adjacent territory of Ashmore and Cartier Islands and as such are solely within the Commonwealth's responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: The five cash bidding areas are those which have been identified as the most highly prospective of the new areas. It is the Government's view that cash bidding is a more economically efficient method than any work bidding system for allocating exploration rights, particularly when, as is likely to be the case here, competition is high. In applying the existing work program bidding system there are very real difficulties for highly prospective exploration areas. Some recent experience in the Gippsland Basin illustrates that difficulty. Three permits were offered recently in that area and a total of 29 applications were received. Those applications represented a whole variety of exploration philosophies, and it became necessary in making the allocation decision to consider factors that went beyond those which the normal best bid approach would have taken into account. Of the three permits that were actually granted in the Gippsland Basin releases one was in fact surrendered after completion of only one-third of the work program proposed; we understand another permittee is now looking for a farm-in partner to assist in further drilling and the third applied to reduce its overall program. Therefore, there can be no guarantee that even with the most careful attention to the criteria appropriate to work program bidding we can get it right.

The central question in the criticism advanced against cash bidding, which no doubt we will hear again in this chamber when the legislation is debated later this session, is whether the introduction of this system will reduce the overall funds available for exploration. There are two important points to consider in responding to that criticism. I acknowledge the very great policy interest that this matter properly generates. I will put it as quickly as I can. The first point in regard to the cash bid permits themselves is that the permittee is free to undertake the most commercially viable exploration program he can devise. In deciding to bid for a permit a company will design an exploration program which will adequately assess the petroleum potential of that permit and the company will estimate the expected returns from that program. If the company also happens to hold a permit in a less prospective area it may well be that the payment of a cash bid for the good acreage will reduce funds, at least in the short run, for the exploration in the other area. While it thus may be necessary for some companies temporarily to divert funds in this way or divert them from other company activity this does not mean that the company will neglect petroleum prospects which are less prospective but still attractive. One other point which is constantly neglected is that a decision to pay cash for a permit is identical to a decision to farm in to a permit, as Senator Durack, when he masters this aspect of his shadow portfolio, will no doubt appreciate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Minister, who has made a particularly long answer, to wind up his answer.

—Mr President, in both cases the company pays a premium, be it in cash or in exploration commitment. A decision to pay such a premium is a normal and common commercial decision. It is interesting to note again--
—Will that be done in Australia?
—Order! I ask the Minister to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Mr President, I find it interesting to note-I hope Senator Durack will also-that since 1980 in the 100 or so off-shore permit areas released there have been at least 50 such farm-in agreements. The funds for these farm-in arrangements obviously form part of a company's exploration budget. Again it may result in some short term diversion from exploration activity elsewhere. But if prospects are expected to be profitable they will not go undrilled. Cash bidding systems of various kinds are extremely common overseas. It is a system which allows for certain very sensitive and difficult decisions to be made by the operation of market forces. I conclude, Mr President--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have asked the Minister several times to draw his answer to a conclusion. He seems to be deliberately trying to talk out Question Time. I ask you to sit him down and enable an Opposition senator to ask a question.

—The Leader of the Opposition would know that I am not in a position to shorten the Minister's answer. But I have made a request to the Minister and I would ask him to see whether he can comply with the request.

—I conclude, as I said I would, as Senator Chaney was getting to his feet, by expressing the hope that journalists like Mr Walsh and those companies whose views he advances-not to mention those of members of the Opposition-would have just a little more confidence in the operation of those market forces whose virtues elsewhere they so routinely espouse.
—Would the Minister table the paper?
—Of course.
